# Chord: 9th in A (Shape: A)

## Brief Presentation
The 9th chord in A, played in the "A shape" on the guitar, adds an extra layer to the standard A chord by incorporating the 9th note in the A major scale. This creates a richer and more colorful sound that can add depth and complexity to your music.

## Notes and Intervals
The notes in the A 9th chord played in the "A shape" on the guitar are typically A, C#, E, G#, and B. The intervals in this chord include the root (A), major 3rd (C#), perfect 5th (E), major 7th (G#), and 9th (B). This combination of notes and intervals gives the chord its unique and harmonically rich sound.

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The A 9th chord, especially when played in the "A shape," is commonly used in jazz, funk, and R&B music. Its lush and sophisticated sound adds a jazzy and soulful flavor to musical compositions. The chord's extended structure creates a sense of tension and release, making it a versatile and expressive choice for musicians looking to add complexity to their music.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the A 9th chord played in the "A shape" on the guitar:
1. "Chameleon" by Herbie Hancock - This jazz-funk classic features the A 9th chord prominently in its funky and groovy chord progressions.
2. "Superstition" by Stevie Wonder - This R&B hit uses the A 9th chord to add soulful flair and color to its iconic guitar riff.
3. "Cissy Strut" by The Meters - This funk instrumental showcases the A 9th chord in a repetitive and catchy riff that drives the groove of the song.
